awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Araminta Wilson is "Factorization Algebras and their Relationships with Quantum Field Theory, Elliptic Genera, Operads, and Deformation Quantization." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Texas at Austin, and the sponsoring scientist is David Ben-Zvi.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The original aim was to study the relationship between genera of field theories and elliptic genera in homotopy theory. The goal of this project morphed into, more broadly, attempting to further the understanding of the relationship between topology and field theory. During the course of this award, the PI worked on several collaborative projects related to this concept. The PI investigated symmetries of topological field theories and ways to extend various descriptions of global symmetries into the language of factorization algebra. The hope is that this framework will increase the number of examples of field theories that can be studied using global symmetry techniques. Work was also done to understand general structures that exist in four-dimensional topological field theories, coming from the inherit categorical framework. 

The PI finished contributing to and editing a book on differential cohomology with Peter Haine and Arun Debray.

Two research talks, and one conference talk were given by the PI based on this work. Additionally, the PI gave an expository talk on factorization algebras to a postdoctoral and graduate student audience. The PI also served as a mentor to undergraduate math majors through the UT STEM Muse program, and helped foster community by organizing several seminars.

 


Last Modified: 03/19/2025
Modified by: Araminta Amabel Wilson
